titleInfo.title: Businesses near Second Avenue and Church Street

mods.abstract: View from the Church Street and Second Avenue intersection showing the businesses along Second Avenue. Signs for businesses on the street include Nashville Store Fixture Co., Nashville China & Equipment Co. Inc., and Acme Moving & Storage Co. The street is filled with cars, including a shipping truck. A man is walking down the middle of the street. The sign for the intersection is visible and a stop sign is hanging from a line. Painted signs on buildings include one on the side of the building for Nashville Store Fixture Co. with their name and Hill Equipment and one on the front of a building for Nashville Paper Stock Co. The sign facing the street for Nashville China & Equipment Co. Inc. says “Enjoy life! Eat out more Often”.

The C.T. Cheek & Son building, located at 184 Second Avenue, is a three-story brick commercial style building constructed in the 1890s. The bottom floor storefront consists of five bays. Brick pilasters extend to the flat roof with stone caps. Masonry on the building includes the limestone stringcourses on each floor and brick corbelling near the roofline and windows. The windows on the upper floors have arched transoms. J.P. Kirkpatrick purchased the property in 1898, and C.T. Cheek & Son, a wholesale grocery store, began occupying the building in 1901. The grocery business was founded by Christopher Cheek, with son Leslie Cheek later becoming his partner. Leslie Cheek purchased 100 acres to build the Cheekwood Estate, including the home and garden, after the sale of the family business. Other previous occupants have included B. Bagg & Son, Nashville Creamery Mfg. Co, Tennessee Glass Co., and Nashville Store Fixture Co. The Drouillard/Nashville Paper Stock Co. building, located at 182 Second Avenue, is a three-story brick Italianate style building constructed in the 1890's for James P. Drouillard. The bottom floor consists of two bays with the storefront featuring a decorative transom area and metal paneling. The building has a patterned cornice and cast-iron Corinthian columns. The four windows on the upper floors have limestone sills, keystones, limestone stone caps, and brick archways. Early Occupants of the building include the Kemker-Woolwine Candy and Cracker Co., John Deere Plow Co., and Parris Manufacturing Co. The Nashville Paper Stock Co. purchased the property in 1922 and operated it for many years. Previous addresses for the building include 8 South Market Street. The building at 178-180 Second Avenue was a four-story brick commercial style building constructed around the 1930’s. The building has pilasters, and stringcourses are located on each floor of the façade. The prior building located on the property was occupied by grocer R.F. Weakley & Co., wholesale grocers Hibbett, Gentry & Co., and harness factory Montgomery-Moore Manufacturing Co. in the early 1900’s. A description of the former building from when Montgomery-Moore Manufacturing Co. occupied it states the building was a six-floor building that was one of the largest on the block. Former occupants of the current building include McWhorter, Weaver & Co., who started leasing the property in 1922, Music City Manufacturing, and Nashville China & Equipment Co. The building located at 176 Second Avenue is a four-story, Italianate-style brick building constructed around 1875. Properties 174 and 176 are nearly identical in construction, with one of the main differences being the arched windows at 176 Second Avenue. Both buildings have similar arched parapets, corbeled brick, window molding, pilasters, stringcourses, and large cornices. The Orr Bros. owned the building from 1876 through 1880, with Robert Orr and family associated with it from 1881 through 1951. In 1890, the building was occupied by Orr, Jackson and Co., a wholesale grocery firm. The company occupied the entire building, utilizing the third-story operating as a factory in 1908 to produce extracts such as O.J. No. 11. Previous addresses for the building include 42, 58, and 60 South Market Street. The Berry & Demoville building, located at 174 Second Avenue, is a four-story, Italianate style brick building constructed around 1875. The building has an arched parapet, corbeled brick, and cornice supported by brackets around the roof area. The top of each window has detailed stone hood molding. The metal cornice above the storefront has elaborate end caps and decorative medallions. The property was owned by Charles Nelson, who also owned 134, 136, and 172 Second Avenue. In 1908, the drug firm Berry and Demoville occupied the building. The C.B. Pearce & Co. building, located at 172 Second Avenue, is a three-story, Italianate style brick building with one bay. The façade has brick corbeling and a cornice with brackets and endcaps near the roofline. The second and third-story rounded windows have Italianate style molding around and arched stone sills with keystones. John S. Heart owned the lot from 1866-1889 before Charles’s Nelson (owner of 134-136 Second Avenue) purchased it. The building was likely constructed around 1885, before the property transfer. Liquor dealers C.B. Pearce & Co. began leasing the space in 1890. Previous occupants include Rich Printing Co., Moneyweight Scale Co., Bell, Long & Geistman, and Acme Moving & Storage Co.
